description: From Middle English chapiter, from Old French chapitre, from Latin capitulum (“a chapter of a book, in Medieval Latin also a synod or council”), diminutive of caput (“a head”); see capital, capitulum, and chapiter, which are doublets of chapter.

definitionGroups.group: (authorship) One of the main sections into which the text of a book is divided.

entries.meaning: A section of a work, a collection of works, or fragments of works, often manuscripts or transcriptions, created by scholars or advocates, not the original authors, to aid in finding portions of the texts.
An assembly of monks, prebendaries and/or other clergymen connected with a cathedral, conventual or collegiate church, or of a diocese, usually presided over by the dean.
A community of canons or canonesses.

definitionGroups.group: A section of a social body.

entries.meaning: An administrative division of an organization, usually local to a specific area.
An organized branch of some society or fraternity, such as the Freemasons.
examples: If the By-Law which admits honorary members is silent upon their rights, they may perhaps be determined by a consideration of which of these classes was intended by the Chapter in admitting them

entries.meaning: A meeting of certain organized societies or orders.
A sequence (of events), especially when presumed related and likely to continue.
examples: "You know that Mr. Armadale is alive," pursued the doctor, "and you know that he is coming back to England. Why do you continue to wear your widow's dress?" ¶ She answered him without an instant's hesitation, steadily going on with her work. ¶ "Because I am of a sanguine disposition, like you. I mean to trust to the chapter of accidents to the very last. Mr. Armadale may die yet, on his way home."

verbs.description: chapter (third-person singular simple present chapters, present participle chaptering, simple past and past participle chaptered)

entries.meaning: (military, with "out") To use administrative procedure to remove someone.
